Sub-Use Case: Identify promising companies in target industries (using databases/news) and compile a list of potential acquisition targets.
Review a company's teaser/CIM and summarize key highlights or red flags to inform go/no-go decisions.
Apply defined investment criteria (size, sector, geography) to filter a list of companies and shortlist those that meet the fund’s mandate.
Compare shortlisted acquisition targets on basic metrics (revenue, growth, margin) to prioritize follow-ups.
Gather and summarize publicly available information (news, filings, financials) about the target company’s market and performance.
Review the target’s financial statements and calculate key metrics (growth rates, margins) to identify any early concerns.
Summarize key insights from expert calls or analyst reports about the target’s industry and competitive positioning.
Compile a list of potential risks or deal breakers (e.g., high debt, legal issues) found in public sources for initial assessment.
Coordinate inputs from various due diligence teams (market, financial, legal) and compile their findings into a consolidated due diligence report.
Track due diligence progress using a checklist; follow up with consultants on outstanding items and update the team on the status.
Summarize detailed findings from consultants (market study data, legal issues) into key points for the internal investment team.
Draft an internal memo or deck section synthesizing all due diligence insights and recommending next steps or deal conditions.
Construct a basic LBO model for a given target, including assumptions for debt, interest, and exit, to project the deal’s IRR and MOIC.
Perform sensitivity analysis on the LBO model (e.g., vary exit multiple or leverage) and summarize how those changes impact projected returns.
Review an existing LBO model for errors or unrealistic assumptions; document any needed corrections or adjustments.
Summarize the key outputs of the LBO model (IRR, cash-on-cash returns) and the main drivers influencing those outputs for the deal team.
Draft the investment thesis section of the memo, clearly stating why the deal is attractive (market position, growth opportunities, etc.).
Summarize key risks and proposed mitigants for the target company in a structured list for inclusion in the memo.
Compile financial highlights (historical and projected) into a concise table or paragraph for the memo’s financial summary section.
Review and edit the full IC memo for clarity, ensuring all key points (thesis, valuation, risks) are well-articulated and supported by data.
Produce a brief industry overview for a specific sector, including market size, growth rate, and major trends affecting investment decisions.
Identify key competitors in the target industry and compare their market share or strategies in a short analysis.
Gather and summarize recent news or regulatory changes in the industry that could impact a potential investment.
Create a SWOT analysis (Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats) for the industry or a niche market segment.
Develop a list of targeted questions for an upcoming management meeting, focusing on areas of ambiguity or risk in the business plan.
Review management meeting notes or transcripts and summarize management’s answers and any follow-up items or commitments.
Highlight any inconsistencies or new information learned from management that should be investigated further post-meeting.
Prepare a brief for the deal team outlining the management team’s background and any known issues, to inform the Q\&A strategy.
Summarize key financial terms of a proposed term sheet (valuation, debt structure, earn-outs) and their implications for returns.
Compare two financing structures (e.g., higher debt vs. more equity) for the deal and outline how each would affect risk and ROI.
Review a draft term sheet for any unusual clauses (non-standard covenants, etc.) and flag them for legal review.
Model the impact of a specific term change (e.g., interest rate increase or additional equity rollover) on the deal's returns and summarize the result.
Outline the key initiatives (cost cuts, new hires, system improvements, etc.) for the portfolio company’s first 100 days post-acquisition.
Develop a simple dashboard of performance metrics (sales, EBITDA, etc.) to track the portfolio company against 100-day plan targets.
Summarize the portfolio company’s progress after 100 days, highlighting which initiatives are on track and which are lagging.
Identify any early warning signs or quick wins from the 100-day data and recommend actions to address them.
For a given quarter, summarize a portfolio company’s financial performance vs. budget and vs. prior year in a brief report.
Consolidate performance data from all portfolio companies and highlight overall portfolio trends (average growth, common challenges) for an LP update.
Draft a section of the quarterly investor letter focusing on notable developments in one key portfolio company.
Create a table of key KPIs for each portfolio company with a short commentary on any significant changes quarter-over-quarter.
Identify recent comparable exits (sales or IPOs) in the sector and summarize the valuation multiples and market conditions of those exits.
Analyze different exit scenarios (sell now vs. in 2 years vs. IPO) and outline the pros, cons, and expected returns for each timing option.
Develop a high-level timeline for an optimal exit (preparation steps, buyer outreach, IPO filing milestones) and key conditions needed at each stage.
Summarize current market conditions (interest rates, M\&A activity, valuations) and advise whether they favor accelerating or delaying the exit.
Review a startup’s pitch deck and summarize its business model, market, and team to determine if it fits the fund’s investment criteria.
Score or rank incoming startup pitches based on defined criteria (market size, traction, team strength) to prioritize which ones to pursue further.
Write a brief 'pass' rationale for startups that are not a fit (e.g., too early stage, overcrowded market) citing specific reasons for the decision.
Identify red flags in a pitch deck (e.g., inconsistent financials, no go-to-market strategy) and document them for discussion with the team.
Analyze an emerging technology trend and summarize the growth potential and key players/startups in that space.
Compare two market segments or customer groups and outline which appears more attractive for investment and why.
Compile key market size statistics and growth forecasts for a niche sector to inform the fund’s strategy.
Summarize regulatory or industry challenges that startups in a particular sector might face, to factor into investment decisions.
Take detailed notes during a meeting with a startup founder, capturing their vision, business model, and any metrics or claims discussed.
Summarize the founder’s answers to critical questions (e.g., about revenue model or go-to-market strategy) for the partnership to review.
Highlight any concerns or follow-up questions that arose from the founder meeting to address in subsequent due diligence.
Prepare a brief post-meeting memo that includes the startup’s key information and the team’s impressions to share with colleagues.
Analyze the startup’s key metrics (user growth, revenue traction, CAC, etc.) and identify any trends or anomalies that need explanation.
Review the startup’s financial projections and stress-test major assumptions (like growth rate or conversion) to assess realism.
Check customer or user feedback (through reviews or references) to gauge product satisfaction and summarize these insights in the diligence report.
Identify key risks for the startup (e.g., regulatory hurdles, dependency on one customer) and evaluate their potential impact on the investment.
Identify the startup’s top competitors and compile a comparison of their product features, pricing, and market share.
Analyze how the startup’s key metrics (growth, engagement, revenue) stack up against competitors or industry averages.
Summarize insights from an industry report regarding competition (e.g., emerging players or substitute technologies) and how they affect the startup’s outlook.
Highlight the startup’s unique value proposition in context of competitors, explaining why it could capture market share despite the competition.
Outline the structure of an investment memo, including sections such as Team, Market Opportunity, Product, Traction, Financials, and Risks.
Draft the market opportunity section of the memo, detailing the TAM (Total Addressable Market) and growth drivers for the startup in a concise narrative.
Write the 'Risks and Mitigants' section for the memo, listing key risks along with how they might be addressed or mitigated.
Review and refine the complete investment memo draft to ensure it tells a compelling story and addresses common questions from the investment committee.
Summarize the key economic terms of the term sheet (valuation cap, ownership %, liquidation preference, etc.) for the partnership’s review.
Compare the offered term sheet terms to market standards or a previous deal to see if any terms are off-market (e.g., unusually high liquidation preference).
Identify any control or governance terms in the term sheet (board seats, veto rights) and note their implications for both the startup and the investor.
Prepare a list of points to negotiate or clarify on the term sheet based on any unfavorable or ambiguous terms identified.
Review a portfolio startup’s monthly KPI report and summarize its performance (user growth, burn rate, etc.) versus its goals or forecasts.
Identify any warning signs in a portfolio company’s metrics (e.g., accelerating burn or slowing growth) and flag them for discussion with the founders.
Draft a brief update email to the partnership about a portfolio company, including recent achievements, challenges, and any requests from the startup.
Provide strategic suggestions or resources to a portfolio company (e.g., introduce a hiring pipeline or a new mentor) based on observed needs, and document this outreach.
Compile a quarterly summary report covering all portfolio companies, highlighting key metrics (revenue, runway) and notable updates for each.
Write a spotlight paragraph on one portfolio company that had significant news (e.g., major customer win or follow-on funding) for inclusion in the LP update.
Aggregate common themes or challenges across the portfolio (such as hiring difficulties or supply chain issues) and summarize them for internal discussion.
Review all portfolio update entries for consistency and clarity, editing out jargon so that Limited Partners can easily understand each company’s status.
Scan recent accelerator demo days or hackathon results and list any startups that align with the fund’s investment themes.
Maintain a database of key contacts in the startup ecosystem (founders met, incubator managers, etc.) with notes on interactions and potential opportunities.
Track tech news and social media for emerging trends or new startups (e.g., a viral open-source project) and share a weekly brief on discoveries with the team.
Summarize insights from recent networking events or conversations in a brief report to keep the team updated on ecosystem developments.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Scan financial news and company filings to identify a potential investment theme or mispriced asset, and document the idea with supporting points.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Generate a short list of new trade ideas each month, each with a one-line thesis (e.g., 'Stock X undervalued due to temporary issue').

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Run a stock screener (e.g., low P/E, high dividend growth) to find 2-3 candidates and list why each might be worth further research.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Monitor a macro trend (like rising inflation) and propose one investment idea that could benefit from that trend, explaining the rationale.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Read a company’s annual report (10-K) and bullet out 5 key insights or concerns that could affect its valuation.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Perform a quick valuation (e.g., calculate P/E or do a simple DCF) for a stock and note whether it appears under- or overvalued relative to its peers.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Summarize the outcomes of a scenario analysis on a company’s earnings (best case, base case, worst case) and the potential impact on its stock price.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Write a brief recommendation note for a stock (Buy/Hold/Sell) including the core investment thesis and key evidence from your research.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Track daily portfolio performance and attribute significant moves to specific news or events (e.g., 'Stock X -3% on earnings miss, Stock Y +2% on FDA approval').

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Create a weekly report showing each portfolio position’s return vs. benchmark and highlight any outliers that drove overall performance.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Analyze the portfolio’s factor exposures (sector concentrations, style factors like value/growth) and summarize any unintended risks or biases.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Explain an unusual performance event (e.g., a sharp one-day drop) by decomposing the portfolio’s returns and identifying which holdings or factors were responsible.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Build a discounted cash flow (DCF) model for a company to estimate its intrinsic value per share, and document key assumptions (growth rates, discount rate).

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Perform a sensitivity analysis on a valuation model (e.g., how does the target price change if WACC or revenue growth changes by ±1%) and summarize the results.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Update a valuation model with the latest quarterly results and note any changes in the valuation or price target compared to the previous model version.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Compare the model’s implied valuation multiples (like P/E, EV/EBITDA) to those of peer companies and summarize whether the stock looks cheap or expensive.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Write a one-page investment thesis for a prospective investment, clearly stating the premise (why it's attractive), key drivers of value, and what the market is missing.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: List the major catalysts for the investment (upcoming events or triggers that could unlock value) and how each could impact the stock, for inclusion in the memo.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Identify the primary risks to the investment and how to monitor or mitigate them; include these in a 'Risks' section of the thesis memo.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Compile supporting evidence (charts, data points, expert opinions) to include in the memo, ensuring each piece of evidence backs a specific part of the thesis.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Summarize the portfolio’s current risk metrics (Value-at-Risk, beta, concentration levels) in an easy-to-read report for the portfolio managers.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Draft a brief explaining the results of a stress test (e.g., market -20%, rates +1%) on the portfolio, highlighting which holdings or strategies contribute most to downside risk.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Monitor for any risk limit breaches (e.g., position size limits, sector exposures) and immediately flag and explain any breaches to the team with suggested corrective actions.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Present a scenario analysis outcome (for instance, the impact of a regulatory change or geopolitical event on the portfolio) and recommend risk mitigations if needed.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Prepare a monthly performance summary for investors, including the fund’s return, a comparison to benchmarks, and a brief commentary on what drove performance.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Write a section of the quarterly investor letter explaining any major portfolio changes (new positions or exits) and the rationale behind each move.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Draft a market outlook paragraph for the investor report, describing how current economic or market conditions are influencing the fund’s strategy going forward.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Create a performance attribution table (breaking down returns by asset class or strategy) and add a narrative explaining the key contributors and detractors for the period.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Track key macroeconomic indicators (GDP, inflation, interest rates) and write a weekly summary of how changes in these indicators might affect the fund’s positions or strategy.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Summarize insights from a central bank announcement or major economic report (e.g., Federal Reserve meeting, jobs report) and distribute the key points to the team.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Research a specific economic theme (such as supply chain disruptions or commodity price swings) and detail its potential impact on relevant sectors or investments in a brief report.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Maintain a calendar of upcoming macro events (central bank meetings, elections, economic releases) and prepare short scenario notes on how each event could impact the portfolio.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Read an expert network call transcript about a company and summarize the expert’s perspective on the company’s prospects in a brief memo.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Highlight critical insights from the expert call (e.g., a major customer trend or a competitive threat mentioned) and share them with the investment team.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Compare notes from two expert calls on the same company to identify any conflicting views, and summarize the major differences in perspective.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Use an AI tool to query the expert call transcript for specific details (e.g., 'What did the expert say about margins?') and extract the relevant answer with context.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Review a new financial regulation or rule change (e.g., updated short-selling disclosure requirements) and summarize how it will impact the fund’s trading or reporting procedures.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Examine the fund’s recent trades for any potential compliance issues (insider trading windows, position limits) and report any findings or confirm compliance.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Prepare for a compliance audit by ensuring all required documentation (KYC, trade logs, approval forms) are organized and summarizing any notable compliance actions in the period.

Sector: Buy-Side Firms (Hedge Funds, Asset Managers, Family Offices)
Sub-Use Case: Summarize an ESG or regulatory questionnaire response for a client or regulator, making sure to clearly communicate the fund’s compliance with the relevant requirements.
Build a merger model for a potential M\&A deal and determine the accretion/dilution to the acquirer’s EPS; summarize the results for the deal team.
Create a detailed DCF valuation for a company under coverage and calculate the implied share price; list the key assumptions driving that valuation.
Audit a junior analyst’s financial model for accuracy and completeness (check formulas, links) and provide a list of corrections or improvements.
Convert the valuation outputs into a simple chart or table for a client presentation, ensuring consistency with the model’s data.
Compile a profile on a company by researching its business model, segment revenues, and competitive positioning, and present it as an internal briefing document.
Summarize key data from multiple industry reports (market size, growth rates) to include in a pitchbook or research report as context for the company’s operating environment.
Identify current industry trends or headwinds (e.g., commodity price changes, regulatory shifts) affecting the sector and list them with brief explanations in a report section.
Write a background section on the industry for an equity research report, covering the competitive landscape and where the company fits in the market.
Draft an outline for a client pitchbook, including sections like Market Overview, Company Overview, Transaction Rationale, and Valuation Summary.
Create slides summarizing the client’s historical financial performance and projections, using charts and bullet points for clarity.
Research precedent transactions in the client’s industry and prepare a slide comparing their valuation multiples and key deal characteristics for the pitchbook.
Review the draft pitchbook to ensure key messages (why this deal or recommendation makes sense) are clearly conveyed and the storyline flows logically.
Write the introduction for an initiation-of-coverage report, summarizing the company’s business and the primary investment thesis in a few paragraphs.
Prepare a quick earnings update note after a quarterly report, highlighting the main beats or misses versus expectations and any change to the investment thesis.
Update the financial model and adjust the rating or price target after new information (earnings or news), and include these changes in the next research note.
Include a clear recommendation (Buy/Sell/Hold) and one-sentence rationale in the research report (e.g., 'Reiterate Buy: valuation remains attractive with improving margins').
Listen to a company’s earnings call live and note key figures (revenue, EPS vs estimates) and quotes to prepare for a quick post-call analysis.
Summarize the main takeaways from the earnings call in an internal email or client note, including any guidance updates and initial market reaction.
Review the Q\&A portion of the call to identify any revealing answers or concerning questions and include those insights in the earnings analysis.
Compare management’s tone and commentary on this call to the previous quarter’s call and note any shifts in sentiment or strategy.
Draft a morning email to clients summarizing overnight market news and notable updates on the firm’s covered companies in a few bullet points.
Respond to a sales team inquiry with a concise summary of our latest view on a stock (e.g., after an earnings change) so they can communicate it to clients.
Prepare talking points for an analyst ahead of a client call, covering the key ideas to convey about a stock or sector and likely client questions.
Review outgoing client communications (emails, report excerpts) to ensure consistency in the message and that they align with the official research viewpoint.
Gather key financial metrics and valuation multiples for a set of comparable companies or deals and organize them into a comparables table.
Calculate the average and median multiples from the comparable set and interpret whether the target company appears overvalued or undervalued by comparison.
Prepare a short qualitative summary explaining differences among comparables (e.g., 'Company A trades at a premium due to higher growth rate').
Update the benchmarking analysis when new data (latest quarter results or new comps) are available and note any significant changes in relative valuation.
Review data room documents (e.g., detailed financials, customer contracts) and highlight key issues or points that could impact valuation or deal terms.
Summarize relevant findings from confidential due diligence materials (like legal or accounting reports) into a memo for the deal team’s internal use.
Maintain a log of all documents reviewed and findings, ensuring the team is aware of important discoveries and any items requiring follow-up with the target.
Compile a list of additional questions to ask the target company’s management based on gaps or concerns identified during document review.
Draft the valuation summary section of a fairness opinion, explaining the valuation methods used (DCF, comparables, etc.) and the range of values obtained.
Compile all assumptions used in the fairness analysis (discount rate, synergy estimates, case scenarios) and ensure they are clearly stated and justified in the document.
Review the entire deal memo for logical consistency and completeness, checking that all required sections (transaction overview, background, valuation, conclusion) are covered.
Summarize the fairness opinion’s conclusion (whether the deal is fair from a financial point of view) in plain language for presentation to a board or committee.
Draft the Management Discussion & Analysis (MD\&A) section for a prospectus or annual filing, summarizing the company’s performance and outlook in compliance with disclosure requirements.
Prepare necessary disclosures and disclaimers for a research report or client presentation, customizing standard compliance language as needed for the specific situation.
Review presentation materials or reports to ensure they adhere to regulations (e.g., no selective disclosure, proper use of public information only) and flag any issues for correction.

Coordinate with legal and compliance to complete required regulatory forms or filings (like a registration statement section or fairness opinion documentation) by summarizing relevant deal information.
Use the expert network’s database to find experts on a given topic (e.g., former executive in Industry X) and shortlist candidates with relevant backgrounds.
Review the profiles or CVs of shortlisted experts for relevant experience and check for any potential conflicts or compliance issues before contacting them.
Write a brief profile summary for each potential expert (their expertise, years of experience, notable roles) to present to the client for selection.
Contact selected experts with a standardized outreach message, tailoring the introduction to explain why their background fits the client’s project.
Read the client’s project brief and extract the primary objectives and questions the client needs answered.
Rephrase a complex or broad client inquiry into a set of concise, specific research questions to guide the expert search and call preparation.
Identify any unclear elements in the client’s request and formulate clarifying questions to get a more precise understanding of their needs (to ask the client if needed).
Summarize the client’s problem statement and goals in an internal email or note so that the team and potential experts quickly grasp what the client is looking for.
Draft a list of 10-15 targeted questions for the upcoming expert call, ensuring all key areas of the client’s inquiry will be covered.
Prepare a brief background memo on the topic for the expert, including context on the client’s industry or specific questions to be addressed.
Highlight key facts or names (e.g., competitor names, industry terms) that the moderator should know and possibly clarify during the call.
Research the expert’s background (past roles, specific expertise) and prepare a short introduction to properly credential them at the start of the call.
Prepare an opening script for the expert call moderator, including introductions of all parties and a quick recap of the client’s objectives for the call.
Manage the call flow by keeping track of time and steering the conversation back on topic if it diverges, ensuring all priority questions are addressed.
Ask follow-up or clarifying questions during the call when the expert’s answers are unclear or when deeper insight is needed, in order to get full value from the call.
Take notes or mark timestamps during the live call to capture important insights, making it easier to summarize key points afterward.
Record the expert call and run an AI-based transcription tool to produce an initial transcript shortly after the call.
Review and edit the raw transcript for accuracy, correcting any mis-transcribed technical terms, company names, or jargon.
Remove or anonymize any sensitive or identifying information (like specific company or person names that should be kept confidential) from the transcript.
Format the finalized transcript with clear speaker labels and timestamps (if needed) to ensure it’s easy to read and reference for the client.
Write a post-call summary that covers the expert’s main insights and directly answers the client’s key questions in either a narrative or bullet-point form.
Extract 5-10 key takeaways or notable quotes from the expert call that capture the most critical information for the client.
Identify any actionable recommendations or next steps mentioned by the expert (e.g., suggestions for strategy) and highlight them in the summary for the client.
Ensure the call summary is written in a client-friendly manner (clear, non-technical language) and double-check it contains no confidential info before sending.
Use an AI tool or search function on the transcript to find the specific answer to a question (e.g., 'What did the expert say about 2024 revenue outlook?') and provide that excerpt to the client.
Develop a list of follow-up questions that arose from the call (topics the expert didn’t fully cover or new questions raised by their answers) to consider for a second call or research.
Index or tag the transcript by topic so that the client (or internal team) can easily search for specific keywords or subjects discussed during the call.
Create a short FAQ document from the transcript for the client, where each original question is followed by a concise summary of the expert’s answer.
Review multiple expert call transcripts on the same topic and identify common insights or consensus opinions that emerge across the experts.
Highlight any conflicting viewpoints between two or more experts and analyze possible reasons for these discrepancies (different experiences, subsector focus, etc.).
Compile a comparative report synthesizing the experts’ opinions into key themes, clearly noting areas of agreement and disagreement on each question or topic.
Present a conclusion or recommendation for the client based on the weight of expert opinions (for example, if most experts favor a strategy, suggest the client consider it strongly).
Scan the expert call transcript for any mention of material non-public information or confidential details and flag those sections immediately for review.
Redact any identified sensitive information (company names, specific figures that should be blinded) from the transcript and summary before they are shared with the client.
Complete a compliance checklist post-call, confirming that no prohibited topics were discussed and that all compliance protocols (like disclaimers, approvals) were followed.
Provide a brief compliance approval note or summary once the transcript and summary are vetted, indicating they are clear of any issues and can be released to the client.
Tag the new expert call transcript with relevant industries, companies, and topics so it can be easily retrieved from the transcript library via search.
Write a short abstract for the transcript (a few sentences summarizing the context and key insights of the call) to include in the knowledge database entry.
Organize transcripts into the appropriate folder or category in the knowledge library (e.g., by industry or client project) and update the index or tracking spreadsheet.
Analyze the transcript library periodically to identify frequently covered topics or high-demand experts, and report these trends to the team for business development insights.

Sub-Use Case: Interpret a user’s natural language query (e.g., 'What was Company X’s revenue in 2022?') and translate it into the appropriate database query, then retrieve the exact figure.
